Here are some thoughts on speciation that probably don't warrant a
deep dis=
cussion but I post them for the record.

Currently sharpneat takes a casual=
 approach to speciation and I'm
wondering if there are improvements to be h=
ad. This ties in with my
recent post about genome compatibilty metrics and =
euclidean/manhattan
distance.

In sharpneat v2 I'm trying to make the code =
base more abstract and
re-usable, e.g. I'm separating the NeatGenome and Ev=
olutionAlgorithm
classes from being dependent on each other and also using =
generics so
that we can plug in new genomes or algorithms with minimum effo=
rt.
Thus my previous discussion resulted in my creating an
ICompatibilityMe=
tric<TGenome> interface which can be plugged in to the
NeatEvolutionAlgorit=
hm.

Looking at speciation again I see that at the outset I simply assign
g=
enomes to species if they are within some distance and if not then I
place =
the new genome in its own species. Independent of this I also
adjust the co=
mpatibility threshold once per generation in an attempt
to keep the species=
 count between some limits (which has its own
problems and is another email=
 in the making). A possible problem with
this approach is that the first at=
tempt at speciation will probably
just assign the first N genomes in the po=
pulation as being the first
genome in each species - these genomes then bec=
ome [temporary]
exemplars for the species, that is, the remaining genomes a=
re compared
against them and if they are close enough to an exemplar they a=
re
assigned to that species.

As an alternative approach I was thinking of =
taking the discussion
about compatibility (or distance) metrics a step furt=
her and actually
explicitly representing where genomes are in the encoding =
space with
something like an IEncodingSpace interface, the idea being that =
I take
the total number of unique connection IDs in the whole population as=

being the number of spacial dimensions, I then define the location of
each=
 genome in each dimension as being the connection weight for that
ID (using=
 0 if a genome doesn't have a connection for agiven ID). From
here I can fi=
nd the range/limits of locations (weights) in each
dimension, which effecti=
vely defines an enclosing hypercube that the
current population is inside. =
I can now divide up the hypercube into
equally sized sub-cubes in order to =
find clusters of genomes that are
close together and use this as the basis =
of my initial set of species.

In addition to all that I suspect it makes s=
ense to keep the exemplar
for each species consistent throughout the life o=
f the species - so a
genome (representing a point in space) we keep to one =
side, that may
have been removed from the population long ago. This keeps e=
ach
species 'anchored' in space and prevents it from drifting. We then
have=
 the choice of keeping a FIFO buffer of dead species as an
indicator of par=
ts of the search space that have recently been
searched - avoiding these sp=
aces when creating new genomes. This is an
idea I raised a few years ago an=
d which I think is known as novelty
search.

Colin.
